_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Introduction and Policies

Plains All American is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations. PAALP?s management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the facility and planned changes to improve safety at the facility.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Cordova Terminal is one of many facilities owned and operated by PAALP.  At the facility, we receive natural gasoline via railroad tank cars.  The received natural gasoline is stored in three 60,000-gallon pressure vessels.  From these pressure vessels, natural gasoline can be loaded directly into tanker trucks for distribution to customers.

Natural gasoline is a petroleum fraction and as such is an NFPA Class 4 flammable mixture.  The lighter molecular weight components of this fraction include butane, 1-butene, 2-butene, isobutene, pentane, isopentane and pentene.  As an NFPA Class 4 flammable mixture, natural gasoline is regulated under the Risk Management Program (RMP) since the quantity of this material at the Cordova terminal exceeds EPA?s threshold quantity. There are no toxic substances present at the site. The facility is classified as Program Level 3 under the regulation. 

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards

striven for by PAALP.  These high standards include:

?Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
?Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
?Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
?Correcting any non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.

Prevention Program

The Cordova Terminal is operating under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees, and emphasis on safety has helped avoid any serious accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  

This terminal is protected by a nitrogen operated pneumatic shutdown system compliant with NFPA 58.  The nitrogen system is plumbed with tubing that if melted in a fire will cause activation of the ESD system. The Emergency Shutdown Valves [ESVs] are forced open with approximately 45 psi of nitrogen. In the event of an emergency, pressing any of the ESD buttons (pneumatic) at the terminal closes the ESVs by dumping the nitrogen pressure that holds them open. There are ESVs installed on the inlets and outlets of each tank, at the truck loading rack and the railcar off-loading arms and associated piping.

Each of the tanks inlets and outlets are equipped with Excess Flow Valves.  If a natural gasoline leak or a piping break occurs downstream of the valve, the valves will close when the gallons per minute settings are exceeded.

In addition, the only way to hook the off-loading hose to the rail car is by using an ESV adapter, which goes from the pipe fitting to the ?ACME? fitting on the hose.  A nitrogen line must also be attached to the adapte

r and opened in order to open the ESV thus allowing natural gasoline product to flow from the rail car to the storage tanks.  These adapters are part of the ESV system.

There are also emergency shut down buttons (electric) that shut down the pumps and compressors by disconnecting the electrical power to this equipment in the event of a stated ?Emergency?.

A combustible gas detection system is installed at this terminal with seven detector heads.  Detector heads are located at:

?2 near truck loading
?1 near the storage bullets
?1 at the compressors
?3 at the rail car unloading rack

The detection system is part of the ESD shutdown system.  In the event that a detector is activated, the detector ?trips? and closes all of the ESVs.  Dumping the nitrogen pressure out of the ESD system closes the ESVs. The ESD system also interrupts the electrical power to all rotating equipment in the terminal.  Fire eyes are also present in the facility which will trigger alarms and shutdown equipment if activated.

Five-Year Accident History

Within the last five years there have been no chemical release accidents that resulted in onsite injuries, death, or property damage or offsite impacts. 

Emergency Response Program

The facility will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary for the terminal with the Cordova Fire Department.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Cordova Police Department, the Rock Island County Emergency Management Agency, and the Rock Island County Emergency Medical Services and, as appropriate, the Illinois State Highway Patrol.  The Cordova Facility Manager is responsible for interacting with these emergency response groups.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the facility is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the publi

c, and the environment during emergency situations.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program, coupled with the Environmental Health and Safety Management Systems, forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

?The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
?The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
?The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.

Specific actions that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the facility include:

?Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements.
?On-going coordination of the facility response plan with those of the town and county.
